title: Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register?
preds: Drastically reducing my forecast based on recent news.
It's Friday the 13th in New Zealand - they're not in session today or tomorrow, so there's no possible way this gets passed before the question ends.
Winston Peter's electioneering has made this goal impossible.

Recent news says it’s not a priority and the government is split. With only a few days to go it won’t happen in time. 
The guardian goes as far as saying that it isn’t going to happen  https://www.google.co.uk/amp/s/amp.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/12/new-zealand-gun-reform-stalled-as-christchurch-anniversary-approaches
Looks like they are continuing to push the decision.

Politics
6 Mar 2020
Gun reforms: Government split over second phase of legislation
5:34 am on 6 March 2020
Share this     Share on Twitter
    Share on Facebook
    Share via email
    Share on Reddit
    Share on Linked In Jo Moir
Jo Moir, Political Reporter
@jo_moir jo.moir@rnz.co.nz The government remains divided over the second tranche of gun reforms and New Zealand First leader Winston Peters cannot say when an agreement might be reached.
Going back to a soft comfortable zero for the rest of the week at least. Echoing the sentiments of @Bengreat and @Benjamin-Yeoh.
Judging from how the debate is going their most likely going to take the debate beyond  March 15 2019
Chances that they will reach an agreement by March 15 appear to have decreased significantly.
Stalled and give now saying 15 March not the important thing but correct compromises/law is important.  (Media reports.)
Cutting my forecast in half as it appears to be meeting some resistance with no movement this week likely.
Per recent news reports (previous forecasts) will probably need to lower forecast further, soon
Just listened to an interview with Peters and he is looking to take pro-gun votes from ACT.
Winnie Peters is playing the populist card as the election looms and New Zealand first is not polling well.

It is unclear how long it may take but the bill is not expected to pass before the first anniversary of the Christchurch shooting on March 15, which had been the Government's initial preference. https://i.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/119997926/continued-delays-to-firearm-law-as-nz-first-sticks-to-its-guns

Lowering this as while discussions have been taking place- it seems votes could go either way. I was up around 50% so decided to take a stance! I do think they will pass the bill but the vote has been delayed- so not sure it will take place before 15 march.
Does not appear to be prioritised on the order paper https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/order-paper-questions/order-paper/document/OrderPaper_20200304/final-order-paper-for-wednesday-04-march-2020

The second part of the firearm law reform will be debated in Parliament this week. Reports say vote could go either way. 
https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/do-right-thing-gun-registry-advocates-opponents-look-convince-nz-first-likely-have-deciding-vote
https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12309787

On Saturday 29 February, the President of the NZ Police Association stated: “This time next week, all going well, Parliament will have passed the Arms Legislation Bill as the second tranche of firearms reforms designed to make all New Zealanders safer.” https://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO2002/S00251/firearms-in-new-zealand-where-to-from-here.htm Yet, as @jayb notes, one article states that “The Government had intended for the bill have its committee stage in the House this week, but it has been pushed back by at least one week.”  Given that Cahill’s speech was on Saturday, this must be a fairly recent development if true. If the Committee Stage has been delayed until next week, it means that the Bill will be discussed on March 9 at the earliest. The New Zealand Parliament website notes that “there is no specific time limit on this stage and members have opportunities for up to four 5-minute speeches on each provision. On large bills of a controversial nature, this process can take place over several days.” https://www.parliament.nz/en/visit-and-learn/how-parliament-works/fact-sheets/pbrief6/#10 I would say that this Bill fits that description given that NZ First have a number of reservations about the Bill, as do lobbyists and other parties. Moreover, it would then have to get Royal Assent.  On the other hand, the New Zealand Parliament website states that the Arms Legislation Bill is scheduled for the Committee Stage and Third Reading this week, which the spokesperson for the Leader of the House hinted at when he said "We're on track to pass the Arms Legislation Bill this sitting block.” https://www.parliament.nz/en/get-involved/the-week-in-parliament/this-week-in-parliament/?fbclid=IwAR11qJAZ-vfaVcOOZTLn0dkTsCLXZyy84dtps3BR-dqdWhIjJ3-eeinROI4 https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12313236 Overall, I put greater credence in the official website of the NZ Parliament, so I’ll keep my forecast very similar. It now depends on how the debate goes and, in particular, how NZ First approach the Bill.

3/2/20 article (link): I'm still seeing conflicting reports about the status of the legislation. https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12313236 Excerpt: "The Government had intended for the bill have its committee stage in the House this week, but it has been pushed back by at least one week."

NZ First supposedly 'on the fence' but so far have supported the bill all the way through to its second reading. I believe this is more political posturing to their base than an abrupt U turn. It would be very late in the day not to support a bill they have helped to put together and supported. Considering the law is overwhelmingly popular with the public at large and the March 15th terror attack is still very raw in the public psyche, I think NZ First knows that electorally it would be more harmful for them to oppose the bill - particularly at this late stage.
(IV) Updating based on article found by Benjamin-Yeoh and confirmations in forecast changes made by bobrown.

(OV) I'm coming into this forecast late.  I'm selecting %65 as my baseline as it's close to the "priced in" forecast value from the team.  I'll start evaluating inside view (IV) and outside view (OV) information from this point forward.
Cutting my forecast in half again based on the update from @Benjamin-Yeoh. The will is there, just not the time to incorporate all concerns.
Watching pertinent developments this coming week

I've changed my mind due to this report: "NZ First may choose to join the National Party and the ACT Party by putting up amendments to the Bill during the committee of the whole House, when the House adjourns on March 3. However, it may instead continue negotiations with Nash, who could put up a Government amendment. It is unclear how long this may take but the Bill is not expected to pass before the first anniversary of the Christchurch shooting on March 15, which had been Nash's preference...." This suggests there will be further delays - will check in after adjornment.  https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/119713576/nz-first-has-reservations-about-new-laws

The bill is due its third and final reading in the first week of March. It rests on NZ first supporting the bill. 
NZ First supported second reading but are being lobbied hard, and asked for some changes. There's also an inquiry publication later in March, which NZ First might say to wait for.  HOWEVER, the PM is pushing hard and most of NZ still have memories of the tragedy last year, so I will put as likely the bill will pass. https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12310276
Cutting forecast in half as no news on progress and days are short to March 14.

Dropping forecast below 50% for now on the shortening (question) time period, conflicting publicly-available assessments + lack of up-to-date info., and vocal public opposition to gun registry. https://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm?c_id=280&objectid=12311958
Braking and downshifting as momentum has been lost for a March 14 date.
I think it will happen, but there isn't enough time b/w now and 15 March
Just not in this time frame. https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/political/409958/further-changes-to-firearms-bill-likely-before-becoming-law

Crucial coalition discussion wont occur until the 9th, and following that, there is not enough time in Parliament to pass SOPs or rejigged Bill. Tellingly, Ardern has dropped all reference to the Bill this year. The Bill doesn't have anything in it that addresses the March 15 shooting, so could be politically embarrassing. They can mark the 15 Mar anniversary adequately without the Bill.
Down shifting as some of the momentum may have been lost as bill gets closer review. Likely to pass but less likely by the stated date.

Dropping the forecast by 1%.  According to the article below, NZ Police Minister Stuart Nash is in talks with parties that have concerns with the bill, but the bill may not pass before 15 Mar, which is Nash's preference.  We should have updates nlt 3 Mar after the House adjourns. https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/119713576/nz-first-has-reservations-about-new-laws
Revising upwards.  Looks like it is moving closer to being passed.  It appears to be a watered down version of the proposed law, but it will still have the gun registry.

Lowering forecast again for now -- mainly reflecting a shortening question time period -- after a conflicting news/analysis report about the bill's prospects of passing by 3/15/20: 
"...It is unclear how long this may take but the Bill is not expected to pass before the first anniversary of the Christchurch shooting on March 15, which had been Nash's preference." https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/119713576/nz-first-has-reservations-about-new-laws https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/political/409958/further-changes-to-firearms-bill-likely-before-becoming-law

The Second Reading was yesterday. The bill is huge - over 100 pages long. Link on this page; • https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill The bill is opposed by the main opposition party The National Party so the proposer of the bill, Police Minister Stuart Nash, is relying on support from a smaller party - New Zealand First - to get it through. However NZF do not support the bill in its current form. • https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/political/409958/further-changes-to-firearms-bill-likely-before-becoming-law Key speech: Ron Mark speaking on behalf of NFZ on Wed 19 Feb 2020 (h/t @Skipper0810); • https://www.parliament.nz/en/WatchParliament/VideoDetail/211147 Crowd: 70%

Increasing from 75% to 85% based on the fact the bill passed its second reading today in NZ's Parliament. 
Increasing likelihood: Today's reading was passed 63 in favor to 57 opposed along party lines. Assuming the final legislation requires a simple majority, the odds are very good it'll get through final vote. 
Uncertainty: There are several aspects of the bill that are still hotly contested. Here's a NZ Natl Party speech that sums them up (https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/tab/video). Depending on how much NZers care about these issues, the CoH and 3rd readings might get more contentious.

Increased to 75% due to the bill passing the second reading.  The bill is on track for 15 Mar. https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill

Moving closer to the current 'crowd' forecast with the bill passing its second reading and continued government push for its passage. Balanced (mainly) with significant written (etc.) opposition + the question's relatively short remaining time period. Will continue to monitor and update forecast as needed. https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/tab/sop (Excerpt:) "A national firearms register and tighter tests for firearms licences are likely to become law after NZ First looks set to support the Government's gun law reforms." https://www.nzherald.co.nz/politics/news/article.cfm https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/119655029/govt-charges-ahead-with-law-to-tackle-gangs-with-guns

The Bill is progressing through Parliament.  Second reading was yesterday.
https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/tab/sop
Passed 2nd reading and is now in CoH stage - will likely pass-through final stages and be given Royal Assent by the 15th March.
Further progress noted, from a second reading, to the penultimate step before a final vote.

Increasing to 62% given that the content of the bill has been reduced.  I'll update again after the second reading, which is scheduled for today.  If the bill makes it through the 2nd reading, then there is a strong chance it will be passed by the symbolic date of 15 Mar.

Input from others have given me renewed backbone to increase my forecast. The watering down may have smoothed some of the bill's rougher edges.
If it actually gets read this week, then I'll move higher.
https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill

starting this forecast at just over 50/50 due to time frame that remains for passage of legislation.  Last semi-automatic weapons ban took 26 days to pass.  With just under 30 days remaining to pass legislation, it is possible but I would need to see more movement into 2nd reading to be more confident that it will pass the bill for a gun register.
Second reading of a bill possible Feb 18th. Will check on it then. If passed on to third reading I will radically change orediction.
A little closer to the current overall 'crowd's forecast, pending further information.

True, but this question regards the legislation. The Select Committee's decision to remove accessories from the Registry requirement lessens the bill's bureaucratic burden and thus makes it more likely to pass through Parliament.

But Gun Control NZ says the Arms Legislation Bill has been watered down too much, and is calling the loosening of proposed advertising restrictions a cop-out. 
The bill is expected to have its second reading next week.
https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12308070 Only the 3rd reading is left and this bill will become law. There is enough time before 15th March.
https://www.parliament.nz/en/visit-and-learn/how-parliament-works/fact-sheets/pbrief6/#5

Good article clarifying (I think) the edits the Select Committee made to the DRAFT Arms Legislation Bill. https://www.sunlive.co.nz/blogs/14360-firearms-legislation-change-is-happening.html  It concerns the Registry, which is handy, because that's exactly what this question is about. Per this PM's perspective, the Registry needs to address the weapons only, not accessories (scopes and bipods have never killed anyone). Thus, it seems the edits the Select Committee made were along common sense lines and, if anything, will INCREASE the odds of this legislation passing through Parliament in the next 31 days. Increasing from 70% to 75%.

The second reading of the bill is on the order paper for Tuesday next week, 18 Feb 2020; https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/OrderPaper_20200218/d6e73981d24fdb0f0f38095ba3ab5b277971eef8 Crowd: 60%.

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register?
I am dropping my forecast as have others, not for the spirit but for the remaining few days available to complete the process.

I'm increasing my forecast based on recent news regarding the review and re-reading of the bill. However, I continue to think passing of the bill by 15 March 2020 is unlikely as the steps to passing a bill (Introduction, First reading, Select committee, Second reading, Committee of the whole House, Third reading, and Royal assent) aren't 50% complete.

I'm decreasing my forecast by 1%.  Numerous have cited this article: https://www.parliament.nz/en/get-involved/topics/all-current-topics/bill-proposes-further-tightening-of-gun-controls/# I assess that New Zealand will eventually pass the bill but maybe not by 15 Mar.  I have read before that New Zealand has the ability to pass bills quickly but am not sure if it can be done within 30 days, especially given that the second reading of the bill has not been scheduled yet.  I will increase or decrease my next forecast based on when the scheduling dates get released.

Bill was reviewed by the Finance and Expenditure Committee and sent back with numerous recommended changes, all of them lessening the strictness of the bill. It will be re-read this week. The proposed changes have frustrated gun control advocates who see them as "watering down" the intent of the bill; in fact, the National Party wrote a minority report that did not recommend the bill in its current form. Nonetheless, it seems more likely than not that the majority will okay the proposed changes or quickly reach a compromise on any particular issue. Gun Control is a popular, common sense idea in New Zealand - consider that the original vote in April 2019 passed Parliament 119-1.
The bill is out of committee and has popular support.  I believe it will eventually pass, but it may not be before 15 March

The relevant Arms Legislation Bill has progressed from its Select Committee to a second reading, which should involve debate and a full house vote. https://www.parliament.nz/en/get-involved/topics/all-current-topics/bill-proposes-further-tightening-of-gun-controls/# The Select Committee's report includes an endorsement of the bill, including amendments that may lower some resistance to the overall measure (e.g., registry exemptions for temporary weapons transfers for the purposes of hunting trips, changes in the fee structure for the registry). report: https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/SCR_93759/dc0896032262699f1094f5c39f08df21c2c19a9f; limited reporting on concerns that have been address through amendments: https://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PA1912/S00119/arms-legislation-bill-report-a-small-victory.htm That said, a second reading doesn't yet appear to be scheduled.

The act is popular amongst most New Zealand residents according to media sources. Additionally, March 2020 will be the anniversary of the Christchurch shooting which directly inspired the beginning of this legislation. Within the Parliament, the act was passed with amendments and seemingly no public outcry against it. Furthermore, Gun legislation has become something of a point of pride in New Zealand because of the quick action taken by the government in 2019. The only reason I predict this outcome as under 70% is because of the speed of the actions taken in 2019 and the issues this caused (specifically with the buyback program). Throughout New Zealand history there have been multiple registries that were less encompassing then the one proposed. I believe the government will choose to roll out this act slower and more completely. They may have it prepared by March but they may wait to begin implementation past the anniversary.
"The Finance and Expenditure Committee has examined the Arms Legislation Bill and recommends by majority that it be passed with the amendments shown." Minority = Nationals and ACT

The bill with amendments has made it out of committee.
You can find the amendments here:
https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/SCR_93759/dc0896032262699f1094f5c39f08df21c2c19a9f

Lowering to around 50-50 for now, pending updates on the legislation's progress. As noted by other forecasters there appears to be significant opposition to the bill via public comments: https://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO2002/S00057/a-mere-7-support-arms-bill.htm

It will be interesting to see what happens, if anything in the next committee session on Friday, 7 Feb
https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/sc/schedule-of-meetings/ If the bill doesn't move out of committee, I think the chance of it getting to a vote by 15 March will drop significantly.

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register?
Do the homework and read the 4K objections to the proposed firearms bill at the website
https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/tab/submissionsandadvice?Criteria.PageNumber=25
This is an election year with the focus turning elsewhere perhaps.
https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill
Feeling less confident about the significance of the anniversary date. Not finding any new information about this topic.

New elections are called for September. This is controversial so unlikely to be passed by this date. I see the PM calling for a registry but no articles that say it has passed or is near. https://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/on-air/mike-hosking-breakfast/audio/chris-cahill-new-figures-on-firearm-seizures-boosts-calls-for-a-national-gun-registry/
New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern confirmed the reforms to gun laws will be announced by March 25.
While there appears to be a fair amount of support, it is an election year in New Zealand.

Establishing a base rate for this question is a bit challenging.  After gun laws in various countries, it is clear that of the 195 countries in the world, most have a gun registry.  Additionally, most developed nations have some form of registry as well, which places the base rate conservatively around 70%.   According to the Washington Post, most gun owners in NZ live in rural areas where there are 26 civilian-held firearms for every 100 people, which is lower than the United States but almost twice that of Australia.  Given the base rate and global precedent, it is highly likely that NZ will eventually have a comprehensive gun registry.  However, the question specifies whether the registry bill will be passed before 15 Mar (the anniversary of the Christchurch shootings).  I have not seen many updates this month in the NZ press.  The last major update was the expiration of the government buy-back program, which the NZ government claimed was a success but the opposition claimed was a failure.  Public opinion appears to support Prime Minister Ardern’s efforts on gun control and registry; however, there is not unanimous support in parliament.  The National Party is opposed to the legislation, and NZ First’s position is unclear.  If I understand the NZ process correctly, PM Adern must have NZ First’s support for the bill to pass.  Additionally, the bill includes more than a registry, which increases the chance of opposition to other parts of the bill.   As a result, I’m decreasing my forecast from the 70% base rate to 60%.  Once the bill status is updated on 10 Feb, we’ll be able to adjust forecasts.  Last thing to keep in mind…the NZ parliament is able to quickly pass legislation.  I’ll be on the lookout for indications on how much political capital PM Adern’s plans to spend on getting this bill passed by 15 Mar.

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register?
I find nothing in the New Zealand press.

Having suffered the March 2019 attacks in Christchurch, the New Zeland populace are supporting the national gun register, but there are still oppositions. The Parliament of New Zeland will probably pass the bill.
The Aussies did it and the Kiwis haven't forgotten.
Adjusting downward due to uncertainty in the NZ legislative calendar.

I started out by trying to calculate the percentage of countries in the world that have gun registries. According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overview_of_gun_laws_by_nation, of the 116 countries they list about 87% (I may have counted slightly off) have full gun registries (like the one proposed), a couple have no registry, and the remainder have registries dependent on type of gun, region, etc. However, it's not clear whether the remainder of countries not listed (primarily African, Central Asian, and some Central and South American) mostly do or do not have registries, so it's a slightly flawed starting place. So I'll un-extremize this base rate a bit to account for that uncertainty, and say perhaps 80% of total countries have similar registries, which would be the base rate if 50% of the unaccounted for countries had gun registries (if I had more time I could do this properly).  Next I think about what it would take for this to happen in New Zealand by that date.
1. Is it possible for it to be passed by that date?
It seems like yes. This bill is currently in the Select Committee, whose report is due February 10. The House sitting calendar shows 12 sitting days prior to March 15 (all after Feb 10), which technically is enough for this bill to make it through the required process. According to @vaska, "The range on how quickly (the next three stages) occurs seems to vary widely, from 1 day to over 1 year: https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/00HOOOCProgressLegislation1/0c2019cc2c015b9752db459669c26a5dfecaa84e" 2. Is it likely to get the necessary votes?
The bill needs a majority of the 120 MP votes. Keeping in mind that the bill has already survived a first reading vote to advance it to the committee. An area of future research for me is how indicative this is of final support. Do MPs regularly vote through bills at an early stage they later vote against? 
The current political party positions are as such:
a.	Act Party- 1 member. Opposes registry. 
b.	Labor Party- 46 members (in Coalition). The Government (led by Arden, a Labor politician) introduced the bill, so while I couldn't find a party position supporting it, it seems likely that they would. 
c.	Greens- 8 members (in Coalition). Party position is to support registry. 
d.	NZ First- 9 members (in Coalition). Unclear. Wikipedia says party position does not support reintroduction of registry, but that is uncited and according to news article (https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12277943) they haven’t decided what they are doing yet. 
e.	National Party- 55 members (in Opposition). Opposes the bill but has made recommended amendments. I need to do more research on what these changes would be and the likelihood of success.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gun_law_in_New_Zealand#Positions_of_political_parties
https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/116470813/national-is-opposed-to-firearms-bill-after-most-changes-it-requested-are-declined?fbclid=IwAR3vRTZASWui0_jXWl7c48fIZSDOcl2khULCbjDl3CoEmMg8XsLea2EZIoU
So if all Coalition MPs vote for this bill, it will pass. That seems to hinge on NZ First, individual MPs, and also whether any National support can be negotiated. There was near unanimous support for the last gun reform legislation, which also seems to nudge in a positive direction. However, that was also among the momentum of the recent memory of the shooting.  3. Which bill could it be? 
The obvious answer is the Arms bill, but could the gun registry specifically be removed from that bill with the bill still passing by 15 March? Is it possible that a new, separate bill just addressing a gun registry will be introduced and passed before then? The latter seems unlikely but I haven't done adequate research on the former.  SO in trying to put this all together into a probability, I intuitively know I want to wind up above 50%. If I start with my base rate of 80%, I am going +5% for the fact that it is possible for this bill to pass in the available time. I am going to adjust downward significantly because of the legislative uncertainty. Which way will NZ First go? How hard is the Opposition line? Are there individual MPs that might break in either direction? Some of these questions can be resolved when I have time for more research, while others will need to be updated with time. I also want to know more about public opinion. Will there be a supportive tide as the one year anniversary of the shooting nears? Are the minority small but vocal? I need more news articles to determine these things, which don't currently exist and will influence the factors described in the sentence prior. -20% for that (an intuitive guess). Which leaves me at 65%.  Other questions:
1. What is the history of gun registry legislation in NZ? Has it been introduced and not passed many times before?
2. There really hasn't been a lot of recent news coming out on this. Once Parliament is back in session in February I think that might change so I will keep an eye out. Also--will the select committee deliver the report on time?

Base rate:
- Difficult to determine here. We could look at the percentage of NZ Parliament bills (over the past 5-10 years, maybe) in the Select Committee stage which make it to the Royal Assent stage within 2 months. Or the percentage of NZ Parliament bills (over the past 5-10 years) in the First Reading stage which make it to the Royal Assent stage within 6 months -- the bill was introduced to First Reading in Sep 2019, which is about 6 months before this question's deadline of March 15th 2020.
- I don't have this data offhand, but theoretically it could be determined using data from the NZ Parliament: https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/all Reasons in support:
- As others have mentioned, March 15th marks the 1 year anniversary of the Christchurch shootings. NZ legislators might see this date as symbolically important, and push to pass the Arms Bill before then. However, as far as I can tell the March 15th, 2020 cutoff is arbitrarily specified by this question. I have not seen any articles in which NZ MPs reference anything about hoping to pass this bill before the 1 year anniversary of the shooting. So I am unconvinced of the importance of this deadline - unless I am missing something?
- Bills in NZ can pass very quickly at times. The last set of gun control measures (linked in the description to this question) passed Parliament only 26 days after the Christchurch shooting. Reasons against:
- It seems like political momentum for gun control measures in NZ is beginning to wane in comparison to the immediate aftermath of the Christchurch shooting. Opposition parties like the ACT, as well as gun owners' orgs, are putting up some resistance. They are also beginning to criticize the first round of gun control legislation from last April as a failure:
     - https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/after-mosque-attacks-new-zealands-gun-buyback-runs-into-an-obstacle-gun-owners/2019/12/20/b4071106-208f-11ea-b034-de7dc2b5199b_story.html
     - https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/20/questions-raised-about-new-zealands-gun-buyback-scheme-as-amnesty-ends
     - https://www.nytimes.com/2019/12/20/world/australia/new-zealand-gun-ban.html
- The Arms Bill's status (https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill) is currently listed as "Report Due: 10 Feb 2020". I'm not totally sure what this means - but it seems like the bill probably won't leave the Select Committee until this occurs? So, after 2/10 that leaves Parliament less than 5 weeks to get the bill through the Second Reading, Whole House Committee, and Third Reading. The range on how quickly this occurs seems to vary widely, from 1 day to over 1 year: https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/00HOOOCProgressLegislation1/0c2019cc2c015b9752db459669c26a5dfecaa84e. Again, an empirical base rate calculation would be useful here. Overall, I'm going with more likely than not that the legislation remains in the NZ parliament having not yet passed by March 15th. Off the top of my head, some factors that might make me change my mind:
- News articles which indicate the bill is gaining momentum (I have not found any such articles since the bill was first introduced in September)
- Articles that indicate NZ legislators are taking the symbolic value of March 15th, 2020 seriously and intend to push the bill through Parliament before then
- Base rate data which indicates that a majority of NZ parliamentary bills pass from the Select Committee to Royal Assent within 2 months
- I learn that the Prime Minister's coalition in support of this legislation is stronger than I thought, and that the bill can pass despite any resistance from ACT or other opposition groups

The report from the Select Committee isn't due until February 10th.  I'm not exactly sure what we're defining as parliament passing this bill (i.e. is it the Royal Assent or just the passage after the Third Reading in the bill process?) Royal Assent can take more time. Assuming it's the passage of the bill by Parliament after the Third Reading, I still don't think there's enough time to get this bill passed by March 15th. If the report from the SC is on time on Februarty 10th (which based on my initial look at the bills that have been recently passed is almost always at least a month behind the the "submission due date" - again, not exactly sure what this means and i could be very wrong about this. but i believe it means when the report is due back from the SC step of the process), we would then go to the Second Reading which takes some time (the fastest i've seen is a week in my initial look at the current legislation schedule and previous bills that have been passed) which then goes to a Committee of the whole house and then a third reading which would all have to happen in 3.5 weeks. I want to scrape the data from the Parliament site and calculate actual quantitative baserates on this information, instead of making calls based on my initial scans of the data. I understand that the one year anniversary of the Christchurch attacks is the intended date of passage and would be symbolic of the nations attitude towards these types of tradegies, but given that there has already been opposition and demands from opposing parties, i think the March 15th is too soon. Things I want to research further:
- come up with actual quantitative baserates for average timing in each step of the bill-to-act process using the information on current and previous bills on the NZ Parliamentary website
- research the current status of opposition of the bills and party demands, also the flexibility the Labor party is expressing in refining the current bill. I have no understanding of how substantial the changes being called for are nor the reactions that have been expressed publically
- understand more of NZ politics in general, i.e. parties, majorities, elections, etc. Links I used to find data:
Current status of the Arms Legislation Bill (this has a helpful graphic that outlines the process of legislation in NZ): https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill
Details of Current and Previous Bills (you can filter by step in the process which I found helpful): https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/previous
Current Legislation Progress: https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/00HOOOCProgressLegislation1/0c2019cc2c015b9752db459669c26a5dfecaa84e

NZ MPs voted 119-1 to outlaw most semiautomatic weapons and assault rifles in April 19 Polls show NZ public strongly supports gun control - https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/after-mosque-attacks-new-zealands-gun-buyback-runs-into-an-obstacle-gun-owners/2019/12/20/b4071106-208f-11ea-b034-de7dc2b5199b_story.html March 15 is the anniversary of the Christchurch attack. Arms Legislation Bill is before the Select Committee and to be reported by February 10. https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/00HOOOCProgressLegislation1/0c2019cc2c015b9752db459669c26a5dfecaa84e
Bills are passed by majority following six step process (select committee is third step). https://www.parliament.nz/en/visit-and-learn/how-parliament-works/fact-sheets/pbrief6/#5 The current parliament, 52nd New Zealand Parliament, was elected in 2017, and the next election will be in November 2020
1 MP resigned since vote but was replaced by another member from same party (National)
PM Ardern is pro-register and head of the Labour, Green, and NZ First coalition majority in house Newsroom NZ article on opposition: "The opposition to the Government's second tranche of changes doesn’t mean it won’t be able to pass the law. As well as a mandate from the horrific event of March 15, votes from Labour, Greens and New Zealand First will do the trick. But as Ardern's Government likes to remind us, lasting change on important issues is better achieved through cross-party consensus." I interpret this information as evidence that the Arms Legislation Bill will pass before March 15, 2020. However, I'm hedging my forecast because timing a big question here. My uncertainties include:
- Will majority parties wait until the day of March 15 to pass the bill, for its significance? 
- How important is unity to PM Ardern? Is it more important than passing this bill before 3/15?
- How likely is it that opposition in National Party or elsewhere could delay the bill?

 Going forward, I'll keep an eye on the bill's progress on parliament.nz and look for public comments from PM Ardern or MPs
Even though there is some resistance, popular support in New Zealand seems interested in further gun control legislation.

UK, Australia, and Canada instituted reforms including registration requirements shortly after gun-related tragedies. New Zealand’s political system can allow for rapid passage of legislation, e.g., the initial measures after the Christchurch attacks. The one year anniversary of those attacks could be a symbolic deadline, yet the passage of time without progress on this effort suggests momentum for reform is lagging. Struggled to find an analogous base rate for something as specific as a national registry following gun attacks given that initial reforms have already been implemented; registration requirements are very common globally, and vary in the specifics. All that said, the government doesn’t hold a majority without support from parties that have not come out in support of this bill; the opposition is actively against it; it hasn’t progressed out of the relevant parliamentary select committee since being referred in Sep 2019; and the interim committee report in December pointed to the array of concerns about the impacts of the bill as written.

I primarily researched 4 things: 1. New Zealand's Arms Legislation Bill (Government Bill 177-1), introduced 9/13/19, that contains a registry.
2. New Zealand's parliamentary process for how a bill becomes a law.
3. New Zealand's parliamentary seats, parties, coalitions, and election cycle.
4. Miscellaneous factors and upcoming events A few research findings (numbers correspond to categories above) 1. a) A factor worth considering might be that 3/15/2020 is the 1-year anniversary of Christchurch. Legislators might push to pass the bill by this symbolic date. I found an article that suggests this possibility.  https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/116047692/aim-for-gun-reform-to-be-law-by-first-anniversary-of-christchurch-shooting
1. b) The National Party has about a dozen proposed amendments to the bill. Still, it seems like they could support the bill once it is amended. And the minority coalition (Opposition) to which the National Party belongs might not have that much leverage anyway, given that Opposition has 57 seats compared to the Government's (which supports the bill) 63. 2. These are fantastic places to research.
https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill
https://www.parliament.nz/en/visit-and-learn/how-parliament-works/how-laws-are-made/how-a-bill-becomes-law/ Using the Parliament website I looked up all Government Bills that became law and started scanning for the ones that could be considered the most consequential and/or controversial. (Note that I am NOT looking at bills that FAILED to pass, so this search has Survivorship Bias.) I used Google to help identify any important recent laws and then I tried to see how they went in order to get a feel for quickly or slowly a bill could become law. What I found was that the process can be amazingly fast compared to the US. The Arms Amendment Bill passed in the immediate aftermath of Christchurch took less than 2 weeks to become law. The Climate Change Response Amendment Bill took approximately 6 months. The End of Life Choice Bill (i.e., euthanasia) took about 2 years (it was introduced on 6/8/17 and passed on 11/13/19). My takeaway was that 3/15/2020 is definitely a feasible date. It depends on the kinds of objections the Opposition has and the Labor Party's willingness to make changes (and it's NZ First and Green Party partners to go along with them). 3. The next election is fall 2020. The last one was fall 2017, and this is when Labor won enough support to form a national government. 4. a) The gun buyback program from the April 2019 legislation didn't seem to be executed very well. In December 2019 it was reported that buybacks were much lower than expected, possibly because the government set the prices too low. Another problem is participants in the buyback program had a security breach involving their private information. I'd think that this episode undermines Labor's promises that the registry legislation will successful safeguard people's privacy. However, I am fairly confident they are not giving up on the registry, because there haven't been any suggestions this would happen. 4. b) The Select Committee's report is due about a month from now, on 10-Feb-2020. I'll be on the lookout for what this report says and any news outlining opposition to the bill. I am having a hard time finding recent news about this bill or other NZ government priorities that might get in the way.
Lowering forecast to 'crowd' level for now, as unable to locate much new, credible info. re this question.

The timing seems unlikely. Proposal of the bill appears to have been a gut reaction and the third/fourth order affects of the registry are now being contemplated, as well as whether the proposal would actually resolve the problem it is trying to solve.
They are still talking about it but some powerful political parties oppose. Do not see it happening that quickly as I can find no pending vote.
Crowd forecast, need to do more research.

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register?
Lots of good analysis, but will a registry become part of any new law. Not clear if the cost of implementation matches the perceived benefit.
While I second the emotion of tighter constraints on fire arms, I am not sure registration is the way forward in the timeframe of this question.

I’m coming down slightly based on.
. NZ and Ardern have already taken action (quickly based on Christchurch attack)
. Ardern (Labour) leads a minority government (operating as coalition)
. Unclear if NZ First (part of coalition) will go along given resistance in rural areas to registration
. Nationals (more seats than Labour and strong in rural area) may not support
New Zealand can look to other countries and see registries can be pricey and don’t stop criminals from getting guns. Restrictions and penalties are cheaper to implement and don’t alienate more conservative voters.

The Government's Finance and Expenditure Committee is currently calling for submissions on the Bill, which has passed its first reading in Parliament. The closing date for submissions is October 23.
https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/116470813/national-is-opposed-to-firearms-bill-after-most-changes-it-requested-are-declined Arms Legislation Bill
http://legislation.govt.nz/bill/government/2019/0177/latest/LMS256911.html Arms Legislation Bill
https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/sc/make-a-submission/document/52SCFE_SCF_BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill

The first round of reforms, already passed into law, outlawed most military-style semi-automatics and assault rifles. A bill that would implement the second round is currently before select committee. It would, among other things, introduce a national gun register and ban visitors from getting a firearms licence.
https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12277738

This seems probably, and the parliament seems to be moving the bill along quickly. However, the coalition partner is opposed and so my main doubts are over the timeline. I suspect it will take longer to get votes together for the bill than expected and that will delay things.

It would seem like the majority of the New Zealand  parliament are for sensible gun control. So far the push back from the opposition has not been on inflexible ideological grounds. Since the "iron is still hot" with the massacre having occurred a few months ago, it is likely that, at least, a watered down version of the proposed bill will reach and get a royal assent

I think they will do this as they think it's the right thing to do.

>Police minister Stuart Nash says the Select Committee considering the bill is now expected to report back by February 10 next year. >That means the legislation is set to be made law before March 15, 2020 - if the Parliamentary schedule allows. https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12270629
The government proposed it, they have a majority, and Kiwis unlike USAmericans are tired of massacres.  Shouldn't be a big problem--although there will be grumbling, some of it justified.

The Government, who introduced the bill, has a working majority in the House (a coalition of the Labour, NZ First + a confidence and supply agreement with the Green party) of 6. It passed the first reading with the full 6 working majority. It has been referred to the Finance and Expenditure Committee, where the Lab/NZ First have a majority. ( https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill) I am expecting this to pass the second reading sometime either in late October/Early November. It will then go to a committee of the whole house (https://www.parliament.nz/en/get-involved/features-pre-2016/document/00NZPHomeNews201311151/committee-of-the-whole-house) where amendments can again be made, but the Gov has a majority and can defeat amendments if necessary. I would expect this bill to pass sometime in January given the Christmas break and the 3 day week of the NZ parliament. The National Party as far as I have read has not objected to a national gun register. There appears to be enough time to get this bill through parliament, and the Government will (>95% chance) survive its term out until September/October next year.
